author: Unreal Engine
description:
Explore how Unreal Engine enables infrastructure design giant HNTB to create flexible and immersive visualizations for large-scale infrastructure projects. Topics include HNTB's custom Datasmith pipeline for importing GIS data and integrating their material pipeline, an interactive callout and chart system, and data-driven tools for construction sequences. 

HNTB's Python editor tools enhance Perforce integration and material creation, and expand customization of PCG foliage with OpenCV. Custom material graphs and HLSL shaders allow their artists to improve fidelity, introduce randomization, and address UV issues directly within Unreal Engine without constant round trips between other software. Finally, the session showcases HNTB's post-process materials for creating stylized environments, object highlighting, and custom mattes for compositing.
title: Transforming Infrastructure Design With Unreal Engine Tools | Unreal Fest Orlando 2025

author: Unreal Engine
description:
Geotech, as an official Epic Games development partner, helped architect and develop Unreal Engine’s Motion Design tool from the start, and remain active contributors to its evolution.

In 2024, in collaboration with Emissive Labs, Geotech took the Motion Design Toolset to the next level by developing a live-events application, venue4D designed to run unreal engine motion graphics in stadiums and arenas.

In this session, Denys Dubinin of Geotech and Danny Tello of Emissive Labs demonstrate how to package your motion design project and generate a game build; control scenes in a packaged game using network APIs; optimize performance for demanding scenarios; and implement your own extensions and package them for distribution. Dubinin also shows how to apply AAA game development best practices to motion design and real-time graphics for media & entertainment.
title: Unleashing UE Motion Design: Packaging and Beyond | Unreal Fest Orlando 2025

author: Unreal Engine
description:
Watch this video to see Riot Games’ Marcus Reid discuss the development team’s reasoning and process for upgrading from UE4 to UE5—and how the move sets VALORANT up for future success.

Riot moved VALORANT to Unreal Engine 5 with the 11.02 patch. The team is looking to upgrade the tools that it uses every day in order to build more benefits for its players, while also enhancing performance across a wide range of hardware. 

Fans can expect better frame rates and more consistent performance across different hardware configurations, along with faster patch downloads that reduce wait time during the game’s ongoing updates. 

Find out more in the blog post: https://www.unrealengine.com/developer-interviews/the-future-of-riots-valorant-is-built-on-ue5
title: VALORANT | Developer Interview | Unreal Engine
